intro: Peucedanum petraeum, commonly known as the rock angelica, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of central and southern Europe. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and dill, and is characterized by its aromatic leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in sunny, well-drained environments. Its flowers are clustered in umbels, a common feature among members of the carrot family. Peucedanum petraeum is often found in alpine and subalpine habitats, where it contributes to the biodiversity of these specialized ecosystems.
